00032 
00033 #define BPMAP_VERSION 3.0
00034 
00041 /*
00042 Outut is a bpmap file; cannot be piped to standard out
00043 
00044 INTRODUCTION
00045  
00046 The BPMAP (binary probe map) file format is used to store the relationship
00047 between (PM,MM) probe pairs and positions on a set of sequences of interest.
00048 The format is binary with data stored in big-endian format.
00049 
00050 OVERVIEW OF FILE FORMAT
00051 
00052 The following lists the sections and their order and placement in the file.
00053 The definition of each section is detailed below.  We assume there are N sequences
00054 and M_i probe pairs mapping to sequence i (for i = 1 to N).
00055 
00056   1 File Header
00057   2 Sequence descriptions:
00058     + Sequence Description for sequence #1
00059     + Sequence Description for sequence #2
00060     + ...
00061     + Sequence Description for sequence #N 
00062   3 Probe-sequence mappings:
00063     + Probe-sequence mapping for sequence #1:
00064       - Sequence ID for sequence #1
00065       - Position Information for probe pair #1 of sequence #1
00066       - Position Information for probe pair #2 of sequence #1
00067       - ...
00068       - Position Information for probe pair #M_1 of sequence #1 
00069     + Probe-sequence mapping for sequence #2:
00070       - Sequence ID for sequence #2
00071       - Position Information for probe pair #1 of sequence #2
00072       - Position Information for probe pair #2 of sequence #2
00073       - ...
00074       - Position Information for probe pair #M_2 of sequence #2 
00075     + ...
00076     + Probe-sequence mapping for sequence #N:
00077       - Sequence ID for sequence #2
00078       - Position Information for probe pair #1 of sequence #N
00079       - Position Information for probe pair #2 of sequence #N
00080       - ...
00081       - Position Information for probe pair #M_N of sequence #N
00082   4 File footer
00083 
00084 
00085 DETAILS OF FILE FORMAT
00086 
00087   1 File Header
00088     1.1 The first 8 bytes always contain the following values, to identify the file:
00089         (octal)                120 110 124 067 015 012 032 012
00090         (hexadecimal)           50  48  54  37  0d  0a  1a  0a
00091         (ASCII C notation)       P   H   T   7  \r  \n \032 \n
00092     1.2 Version number, float. Valid versions are 1.0, 2.0 and 3.0. (4 bytes)
00093     1.3 N, the number of sequences, stored as an uint32_t (4 bytes).
00094 
00095   2 Sequence Descriptions - the next N blocks (one for each sequence) respect the following format:
00096     Note that the N blocks are required to be in a specific order, to enable fast searches.
00097     The ordering of sequences is defined by:
00098          Lex sort on sequence group name (version >= 2.0 only),
00099          Lex sort on sequence version (version >= 2.0 only),
00100          Lex sort on Sequence name
00101     2.1  Length of the sequence name, uint32_t (4 bytes) 
00102     2.2  Sequence name stored as a sequence of chars, length specified by 2.1 above.
00103     ---- Items 2.3-2.4 are only present in versions >= 3.0 of the format ----
00104     2.3  Probe Mapping type, unsigned int (4 bytes)
00105          0 indicates a (PM,MM) probe pair tiling across the sequence.
00106          1 indicates a PM-only tiling across the sequence.
00107     2.4  Sequence file offset, unsigned int (4 bytes)
00108          The offset (in bytes) of the probe-sequence mapping info in section 3, after the
00109          end of the sequence description section.  Intended to enable fast look-up ability.
00110     ---- End version >= 3.0 specific section ----
00111     2.5  Number of probes/probe pairs in the sequence, uint32_t (4 bytes)
00112     ---- Items 2.6 through 2.10 are only included if the version is >= 2.0 ----
00113     2.6  Length of the sequence group name, uint32_t (4 bytes)
00114     2.7  Sequence group name (such as the organism to which the sequence belongs) stored as chars, length specified by 2.6
00115     2.8  Length of the sequence version, uint32_t (4 bytes)
00116     2.9  Sequence version stored as chars, length specified by 2.8
00117     2.10 Number of meta-data tag-value pairs, uint32_t (4 bytes)
00118         For each meta-data tag-value pair we store the following:
00119         2.10.1 Length of key in meta data block, uint32_t (4 bytes)
00120         2.10.2 Key in meta data block stored as chars, length specified by 2.10.1
00121         2.10.3 Length of value in meta data block, uint32_t (4 bytes)
00122         2.10.4 Value in meta data block stored as chars, length specified by 2.10.3
00123     ---- End version >= 2.0 specific section ----
00124   3 Probe-sequence mappings - the next N blocks (one for each sequence) respect the following format:
00125     3.1 Header info specific to the sequence
00126         3.1.1 Sequence ID, uint32_t (4 bytes)
00127     3.2 The next M_i blocks (one for each probe or probe pair aligning to the sequence, from 2.3) respect the format below.
00128         Note that the N blocks are required to be in a specific order, to enable fast searches.
00129         The ordering is defined as follows:
00130           Numeric sort on position
00131           Numeric sort on strand indicator
00132           Numeric sort on X coordinate of PM probe
00133           Numeric sort on Y coordinate of PM probe
00134           Numeric sort on X coordinate of MM probe (if there is an MM)
00135           Numeric sort on Y coordinate of MM probe (if there is an MM)
00136         3.2.1 X coordinate (0-based) on array of the PM probe as uint32_t (4 bytes)
00137         3.2.2 Y coordinate (0-based) on array of the PM probe as uint32_t (4 bytes)
00138         --- in versions >= 3.0 the next two sections are skipped if the mapping type is PM-only, as indicated in 3.2.1 ---
00139         3.2.3 X coordinate (0-based) on array of the MM probe as uint32_t (4 bytes)
00140         3.2.4 Y coordinate (0-based) on array of the MM probe as uint32_t (4 bytes)
00141         3.2.5 Length of the PM (and MM if a probe pair) as unsigned char (1 byte)
00142         3.2.6 DNA Probe sequence. The probe sequence is packed into a 7 byte sequence of chars.
00143               Each byte represents up to 4 bases (so the format can handle probes of length up to 27bp).
00144               The first byte contains the first 4 bases of the probe.
00145               The first base of the probe is encoded in the two most significant bits of the first byte.
00146               The fourth base of the probe is encoded in the two least significant bits of the first byte.
00147               The conversion from each pair of bits to a DNA base is as follows: (0,1,2,3) -> (A,C,G,T)
00148         3.2.7 Match score as float (4 bytes).
00149               The current BPMAP files are based on perfect 25-mer alignment so the scores are 1. (4 bytes)
00150         3.2.8 Position of PM probe within the sequence as uint32_t (4 bytes).
00151               The position is the 0-based position of the lower coordinate of the 25-mer aligned to the target.
00152         3.2.9 Strand indicator as unsigned char (1 byte).
00153               Value is 1 if the matching target (not the probe) is on the forward strand, 0 if on the reverse.
00154 */
